attributes.alt: Book cover for The One Day House by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz. The cover art shows a boy drawing with chalk on a sidewalk in front of a house.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce the big book and identify it as a narrative about Wilson and Gigi.
Use Circle Time to introduce the vocabulary word
Use Circle Time to review the letters
Begin Story Time by introducing the big book and asking the guiding question:
What are some things Wilson plans on doing one day?
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds;  Identify at least 20 uppercase  and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Understand that people who speak the same language sometimes use different dialects or expressions.
Allow children to uncover clues using paint, and find a partner with a matching letter.
Explore children’s vocabulary by finding words that contain these sounds and trying to define them.
What can we do better together?
What character is in your book? What’s special about that character?
Can you pretend you’re going to help fix Gigi’s house?
Can you draw a house with five windows?
Can you write what you like about your neighborhood?
Can you use these materials to make Gigi’s house?
Can you find things in your station that start with the  letter
Build a fence using materials from the construction center.

attributes.alt: Book cover for The One Day House by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz. The cover art shows a boy drawing with chalk on a sidewalk in front of a house.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice identifying and solving problems, and introduce related vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Make inferences; Make predictions; Relate own experiences to those in books;  Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words; Make connections between words and real life.
Connect to the Big Book by encouraging children to identify problems and find solutions like Wilson does.
Extend learning by comparing solutions and discussing consequences.
What can we do better together?
Can you identify the problem in the story?
Can you pretend to solve the problem of a broken chair?
Can you draw Gigi’s flower garden? How many flowers did you draw?
Write a story about a time you asked for help.
Can you use these materials to create Gigi’s flower garden?
Can you find things in your station that start with the  letter
Can you build a house like  Gigi’s?

attributes.alt: Book cover for The One Day House by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz. The cover art shows a boy drawing with chalk on a sidewalk in front of a house.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and teach vocabulary
Why does Wilson want to help Gigi?
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds;  Identify at least 20 uppercase  and lowercase letters in text.
Make inferences; Make predictions; Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Compose a narrative; Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Help children create stories involving the letters
Encourage children to speak using complete sentences.
What do we do better together?
How do the characters in your book work together?
Can you pretend to be someone that helps Gigi? What will you fix?
What is one tool you can use to measure something?
Write a story about how Wilson asked his neighbors to help Gigi.
Can you use these materials to make a dog for Gigi?
Can you find things in your station that start with the  letter
Can you build a fence, like Gigi has in her yard?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for We Have Soup! The chart says, We have peas. We have corn. We have carrots. Hooray for vegetable soup!

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  We Have Soup

attributes.alt: Book cover for The One Day House by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz. The cover art shows a boy drawing with chalk on a sidewalk in front of a house.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about teamwork, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to make a connection with the weekly concept question,
What do we do better together?
Select books and other texts for prereading.
Make inferences; Compare and contrast two stories relating to the same topic.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Encourage children to work as a team.
Ask them to complete an art project together.
Challenge them to discuss why we do some things better together than alone.
What do we do better together?
Did you find a book? Why did you pick this book?
Can you pretend to make soup for everyone?
Can you draw a bowl of vegetable soup? Count how many vegetables you used.
Can you write a story about making soup? Who will help you make the soup?
Can you fill this bowl with things to make soup?
Now let’s make Alphabet Soup using the tiles. See if you can spoon out a word!
Can you build the town of Rabbitville?

attributes.alt: Book cover for The One Day House by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz. The cover art shows a boy drawing with chalk on a sidewalk in front of a house.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and teach vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question:
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Select books and other texts for prereading.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Tell about a time you worked together with many other people.
Save children’s work to display next week.
What do we do better together?
Can you find a book you want to read? What do the pictures tell you about the book?
Can you pretend to be Wilson? Can you ask different people to help you fix Gigi’s house?
Can you draw the neighbors helping Wilson and Gigi? How many people did you draw?
Can you write about how you would help Gigi?
Can you use these materials to make the group of people helping Gigi?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a friend?
Can you build a house that looks like Gigi’s house? Ask for help and work as a team!
